page.title: 01SOUTH CENTRAL GATESHEAD 1
page.content: Physically this 'D' block consists of a ridge of Carboniferous Sandstone rising to 152m(500') with lowland to the East and West. The sandstone has been quarried in the past although most of the quarries are now disused. In the West the ridge descends into a wide flat floored valley at present occupied by a small stream - the River TEAM - much of which flows in a culvert. Coalmining attracted many people to this area in the 19th century, the mines have been exhausted and now little sign of their existance remains. The mining is now represented by the tracks of old railways, now forming a system of footpaths, and an area of urban open space on the graded flanks of spoil heaps now grass covered.
